text: Again, what was he can, he can?
Il peut.
He can do it.
Il peut le faire.
He can do it this evening.
Il peut le faire ce soir.
He can't do it this evening.
Il ne peut pas le faire ce soir.
Again, it's important to remember to sandwich the word can in this sentence.
So again, he can is...
Il peut.
And he cannot, you will make a sandwich again with the ne, the negative warning,
and the pas that goes at the end.
So, he cannot will be...
Il ne peut pas.
So there we have it.
Slowed down, it is...
Il ne peut pas.
And even slower...
Il ne peut pas.
Again, round the pa, you can see those two slices of bread effectively, the ne and the pa.
It's similar to the English where we will say he cannot, but it has the additional slice of bread,
which is the negative warning that the word not is coming up.
It's important in French when you're going to say something negative.
You may hear when French speakers...
French native speakers actually speak the language.
They may sometimes omit it.
This is very naughty and you shouldn't do it, as it will help you be less clear rather than better understood.
So, how would you say he can't take a taxi?
Il ne peut pas prendre un taxi.
How about she can?
Il ne peut.
You in formal can using tu.
Tu peut.
Again, be careful with the pronunciation of tu.
Many English speakers will simply say tu.
Like the English number tu.
However, that's not the correct pronunciation.
There's a vowel sound here that doesn't exist in English.
And it's made correctly in French by rounding your lips as though you're going to whistle.
And so, for instance, if you want to say this correctly, you'll round your lips and say the word tea,
but with your lips still rounded.
So, instead of it coming out as tea, your lips will be rounded and it will come out as tu.
Tu.
How would you say you can in that case?
Tu peux.
You can eat it.
Tu peux le manger.
You can eat it this evening.
Tu peux le manger ce soir.
You can understand.
Tu peux comprendre.
You can understand me.
Tu peux me comprendre.
How would you change it into a question and say,
can you understand me?
You use the rising intonation at the end and say,
you can understand me?
Tu peux me comprendre.
Very good.
So, again, to understand me is...
Me comprendre.
As mentioned earlier, the tu form is very familiar in French.
Now, as a bit of advice, I would suggest to anyone learning French not to introduce tu into a conversation.
Frequently, for English speakers, it seems unusual to be formal with people.
You might feel that the French person would be more comfortable if you address them as tu.
However, this really is quite a familiar thing to do in French.
And the way to know when to use tu correctly is simply to see whether a French person uses it with you.
That's the best rule of thumb.
If another adult feels comfortable using it with you, it's generally going to be safe back.
It's also going to be the form you're going to use if you talk to children.
If you address small children as vous, it will sound a bit funny in French because you'll be being extremely polite to them
and showing them perhaps a little more respect than you normally would to little children.
The other way to address someone as you is, of course, vous.
So, how would you say you can?
Vous pouvez.
How would you say you can keep the change?
You can guard the money.
You can guard the money.
How would you say can you keep the change?
Pouvez-vous garder la money?
What about we can?
Nous pouvons.
We can understand.
Nous pouvons comprendre.
We can understand it.
Nous pouvons le comprendre.
We can understand you.
Nous pouvons vous comprendre.
Finally, they can understand you.
Ils peuvent vous comprendre.
And then let's try they can understand you and the they we're referring to is an entirely female group.
Elles peuvent vous comprendre.
Elles peuvent vous comprendre.
Thank you.
